title-group.article-title: Phenylethynyl-endcapped polymerizable monomer reactants poly(amic ester) resins for high impact-toughened carbon fiber composites

article-meta.aff: 1Laboratory of Advanced Polymer Materials, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China
2Graduate University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing, China

author-notes.corresp: Shiyong Yang, Laboratory of Advanced Polymer Materials, Institute of Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100190, China. Email: shiyang@iccas.ac.cn

abstract.p: Toughened polymerizable monomer reactants (PMR) poly(amic ester) matrix resins were prepared by the reaction of the diesters of aromatic dianhydrides (3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic dianhydride (BPDA) and/or 2,3′,3,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic dianhydride) and aromatic diamines (the mixture of 3,4′-oxydianiline and 1,3-bis(4-aminophenoxy)benzene) in the presence of monoester of 4-phenylethynyl phthalic anhydride as the end-capping agent using ethanol as solvent. The PMR matrix resins owned the characteristic of high resin concentration and low viscosity, suitable for impregnating carbon fibers (Cfs) to give high-quality Cf prepreg. The B-staged imide oligomers prepared by thermal baking of the PMR matrix resins at the temperature of ≤240°C showed good meltability at elevated temperatures. The polyimide (PI) neat resins prepared by thermally curing the B-staged oligoimide resins at 370°C showed good combined thermal and mechanical properties. The Cf/PI composite (T300/PI) showed high impact toughness, with compression strength after impact of as high as 260 MPa. Unidirectional laminates had high mechanical properties at room temperature and high strength retention at 250°C, with 97.4% for flexural modulus, 53.3% for flexural strength, and 48.8% for interlaminar shear strength, demonstrating that the high impact-toughened Cf/PI composite could be long-term served at a temperature as high as 250°C.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p:
Carbon fiber polyimide (Cf/PI) composites, due to their great combination of thermal and mechanical properties, have been widely employed in aerospace and air-engine applications in recent years. 1–4 Lots of research have been performed on the development of high temperature PI composites. 5–8 However, there are still some drawbacks for Cf/PI composites such as poor melt processability and low impact toughness, which have hampered their extensive applications. Generally, thermoplastic PIs offer excellent impact toughness due to their high-molecular-weights, but show poor melt-processability derived from their high melt viscosities. In comparison, thermosetting PIs show low melt viscosities, resulting in good melt-processability, but usually exhibit low impact toughness due to highly cross-linked chemical structures. Hence, seeking for the balance of the polymer chain length and the cross-linking degree has always been considered as an effective way to obtain PI matrix resins with both desirable melt-processability and high impact toughness. For instance, polymerizable monomer reactant (PMR)-15, a representative thermosetting PI, 7
,9 is brittle in nature, resulting in the Cf/PMR-15 composites with compression strength after impact (CAI) of 170–190 MPa at the impact energy of 6.7 kJ m−1. In comparison, the phenylethynyl-endcapped PIs, such as phenylethynyl-terminated imide (PETI)-5 with the calculated molecular weight (Calcd M n) of 5000 g mol−1, have attracted much attention due to their good toughness. 10–16 The Cf/PETI-5 composite was reported to show CAI values of over 320 MPa. 17 One problem for this composite was its poor processing properties. High boiling point and strong polar solvents (such as N-methyl-2-pyrrolidinone (NMP)) have been employed to prepare the Cf prepreg due to poor solubility of PETI-5 in common solvents. 18
,19 Another problem is the high melt viscosity of PETI-5 oligomer. 20 Hence, PI matrix resins with both high impact toughness and good processabilities are desired for the Cf composite applications.

In this article, a modified PMRs method was developed to prepare the molecular-weight-controlled phenylethynyl-endcapped poly(amic ester) resins. The PMR poly(amic ester) resins were prepared using ethyl alcohol as solvent to give a high solid content solutions with low solution viscosity, suitable for impregnating with Cfs to produce high-quality prepregs. The Cf composites could be produced by thermal curing the prepreg. Effect of chemical structures of polymer and the polymer molecular weights on the PI properties has been systematically investigated. The mechanical and thermal properties of the Cf composites including the damage tolerance have also been evaluated.

sec.title: Starting materials
sec.p: 4-Phenylethynyl phthalic anhydride (4-PEPA), s-BPDA, α- BPDA, 3,4′-ODA (3,4′- Oxydianiline), and 1,3,4-APB (1,3-Bis(4-aminophenoxy)benzene) were purchased from POME Sci-tech Co. (China) and used as received. Commercially available NMP, N,N′-dimethylacetamide (DMAc), N,N-dimethylformamide, toluene, methanol, ethanol, butyl alcohol, and dioxane were purchased from the Chemical Reagent Beijing Co., Ltd. Continuous T300 (12 K) Cf was purchased from Toray (Japan).

sec.title: Preparation of the PMR poly(amic ester) matrix resins
sec.p: The phenylethynyl-endcapped poly(amic ester) resins were prepared by the reaction of diester of 3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic dianhydride (BPDA; s-BPDA, and/or α-BPDA) and the monoester of 4-PEPA with the aromatic diamines mixtures. In a typical experiment, mixture of s-BPDA or/and α-BPDA and 4-PEPA were first refluxed for 3 h in ethanol/DMAc (5:1) to form Biphenyltetracarboxylic diester (BPDE) (the diester of s-BPDA or/and α-BPDA solution) and Phenylethynylphthalic acid monoester (PEPE) (the monoester of 4-PEPA solution), respectively. Then, the mixture of 3,4′-ODA and 1,3,4-APB were added with stirring in one portion to the solution of BPDE and PEPE to afford the PMR poly(amic ester) solution with solid content of ∼50% and Brookfield viscosity of 40–50 mPa·s at 25°C.

sec.title: Preparation of thermally cured PI neat resins
sec.p: The solution of PMR poly(amic ester) resin was evaporated with a rotary evaporator at 60°C to remove most of the solvents to give a viscous solution, which was then cumulatively staged at 70°C/3 h, 120°C/1 h, 150°C/1 h, 180°C/1 h, and 240°C/1 h in vacuum to yield the B-staged phenylethynyl-endcapped oligoimide resin powders. The B-staged oligoimide resin was thermally cured by hot press at 370°C/2 h and 1.5 MPa to form the thermally cured PI neat resins.

sec.title: Melt processing of the Cf/PI composite laminates
sec.p: The PMR poly(amic ester) resin solution with solid content of 50% and a Brookfield viscosity of 40–50 mPa·s at 25°C was employed to impregnate the continuous Cf to produce the Cf prepreg. The as-prepared prepreg was dried in air at room temperature for 2 days, then cut into plies and plied up. The Cf/PI composite laminates were fabricated by thermally curing of the plied-up prepregs in a hot press. The composite prepreg layup was cumulatively staged at 120°C/1 h, 180°C/1 h, and 240°C/1 h to give a prepreg with B-staged oligoimide/fiber layup under a contact pressure. A pressure of 1.5 MPa was applied when the temperature was increased to 350°C. The temperature was further increased to 370°C/2 h under the applied pressure. After the composite laminates in the mold were cooled to about 100°C, the applied pressure was subsequently released. The composite laminate panels were C-scanned and cut into test specimens for testing the mechanical properties.

sec.title: Characterization and measurements
sec.p: The absolute viscosity of the PMR poly(amic ester) resin solution was measured on a Brookfield DV-II+ viscometer at 25°C. Fourier transform infrared (FTIR) spectra were recorded on a Tensor 27 Fourier transform spectrophotometer. Wide-angle x-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements were conducted on a Rigaku D/max-2500 x-ray diffractometer with Cu/Ka radiation, operated at 40 kV and 200 mA. The number average molecular weights (M n) and polydispersities (M w/M n) were determined by gel permeation chromatography (GPC) on a Waters GPC system equipped with a Waters 1515 HPLC pump, a Waters 2414 differential refractometer, and three Styragel columns of HT-3, HT-4, and HT-5, using NMP as the eluent at a flow rate of 1.0 mL min−1 at 35°C.

Rheological measurements were carried out on a TA AR2000 rheometer. Specimen disks (25 mm in diameter and 1.5 mm thickness) were prepared by compression molding of the B-staged imide oligomer resin powder at room temperature. The disk was then loaded in the rheometer fixture with 25-mm diameter parallel plates. The top plate was oscillated at a fixed strain of 0.5% and a fixed angular frequency of 10 rad s−1 , while the lower plate was attached to a transducer, which recorded the resultant torque.

Differential scanning calorimetry (DSC) was conducted on a TA Q100 thermal analysis system in nitrogen atmosphere at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. Thermogravimetric analysis was performed on a TA Q50 thermal analysis system at a heating rate of 20°C min−1 in a nitrogen atmosphere at a flow rate of 60 cm3 min−1. Dynamic mechanical analysis (DMA) was performed on a TA Q800 thermal analysis system with a heating rate of 5°C min−1 and a frequency of 1 Hz. A three-point bending mode was employed with the specimen size 15.0 mm × 5.0 mm × 1.5 mm.

The cross-sections of the composite laminates were investigated through an optical microscope (Vision Engineering Co., UK), which was coupled to a charge coupled device (CCD) camera and connected to a desktop computer. C-Scan was performed with a probe frequency of 20 M on an automated ultrasonic testing provided by LEEPIPE Inspection Technologies Inc.

Mechanical properties of the thermally cured PI neat resins and unidirectional T300/PI composites were measured on an Instron 5567 universal testing machine. Flexural strength and modulus for neat resins were obtained with 3-mm-wide specimens at a span to depth ratio of 16 at a rate of 1.0 mm min−1 in accordance with HG/T 3840-2006. Tensile strength and modulus tests for neat resins were carried out with 5-mm-wide specimens at a rate of 2.0 mm min−1 in accordance with GB/T 16421-1996. The interlaminar shear strength of the T300/PI composite laminates was measured on 12-ply unidirectional specimens, 20 mm by 6 mm, at a span to depth ratio of 5 according to GB/T 1450.1-2005. The flexural strength and modulus of the composite laminates were obtained on 12-ply unidirectional specimens, 80 mm by 12.5 mm, at a span to depth ratio of 32 according to GB/T 3356-1999. The open-hole compression strength (OHC), open-hole tensile strength (OHT), and CAI of the composite laminates were measured on an Instron 8506 testing machine. The OHC strength of the laminates was obtained on 16-ply quasi-isotropic specimens 150 mm by 38 mm with a 6.3-mm hole in the center in accordance with HB 6741-1993. The OHT strength of the laminates was obtained on 16-ply quasi-isotropic specimens 180 mm by 38 mm with a 6.3-mm hole in the center in accordance with HB 6740-1993. CAI was determined on 24-ply quasi-isotropic specimens 150 mm by 100 mm, which were impacted at a stress level of 6.7 kJ m−1 before tested in accordance with GB/T 21239-2007, wherein the impact tests were performed on a LC-300B Falling dart tester.

sec.title: Synthesis of the PMR poly(amic ester) resins
sec.p: The solubility of the diester of aromatic dianhydrides in low boiling point alcohol solvent has been considered a key issue for successful preparation of PMR resins. To prepare a solution of PMR resin, aromatic dianhydrides and an endcapping agent have to be esterified and dissolved in alcohol solvents, and aromatic diamines are then dissolved in this blend by the reaction of acid groups and amino groups. In order to obtain a homogeneous solution of the diester of BPDA (s-BPDA and α-BPDA), in this work, 20% of DMAc was blended with ethyl alcohol to form a solvent mixture, which was then employed as the solvent for the esterification of s-BPDA and α-BPDA to provide a homogeneous solution of s-/α-BPDE.

The solution of s-/α-BPDE was then mixed with the alcohol solution of PEPE to give a homogenous solution of s-/α-BPDE and PEPE, to which the solid mixture of 1,3,4-APB and 3,4′-ODA was added with stirring for 2 h to give a homogenous A-staged PMR poly(amic ester) resin solution as shown in Figure 1. The PMR resin solutions have high solid concentration (∼50%) and low viscosities (40–50 mPa·s), suitable to impregnate Cf to yield prepregs with high solid resin loadings. It was found that the PMR poly(amic ester) resin solutions were very stable, no phase separation or gelation was detected during the storing at room temperature.

caption.p: Preparation of the PMR poly(amic ester) matrix resins. PMR: polymerizable monomer reactant.

sec.p: Thus, a series of PMR poly(amic ester) solutions with two different Calcd M n (5000 g mol−1 and 2500 g mol−1, respectively) and five different chemical compositions were prepared as shown in Table 1. Their structures and properties were discussed in the following sections.

caption.p: Chemical compositions of the PMR poly(amic ester) matrix resins.

fn.p: PMR: polymerizable monomer reactant; PI: polyimide; Calcd M n: calculated molecular weight; BPDA: 3,3′,4,4′-biphenyltetracarboxylic dianhydride.

sec.title: Chemical structures of B-staged oligoimide resins
sec.p: After impregnated with Cf to produce a high-quality prepreg, the A-staged PMR poly(amic ester) matrix resins in the prepreg will be thermally changed into B-staged oligoimide resin before the formation of Cf/PI composites, wherein the meltability of the B-staged oligoimide resins is the key issue for the composite fabrication.

Figure 2 depicts the changes in DSC curves of the PMR A-staged poly(amic ester) resins with different thermal baking temperatures. It can be seen that no obvious changes in DSC curves could be detected for the PMR poly(amic ester) resins with baking temperature of >150°C. The strong endothermic peak at 170°C could be attributed to the evaporation of DMAc, which was almost disappeared for the samples treated at >180°C.

caption.p: DSC curves of a PMR poly(amic ester) resin (PI-1) with different thermal baking temperatures. DSC: differential scanning calorimetry; PMR: polymerizable monomer reactant; PI: polyimide.

sec.p: The changes in FTIR spectra of the PMR poly(amic ester) resins with different thermal baking temperatures were compared in Figure 3. It is clear that no obvious chemical changes could be detected for the samples baked at >180°C. However, there was an abrupt loss in the sample mass when the baking temperature was increased from 180°C to 200°C (Figure 4), which could be attributed to the imidization of poly(amic ester) resins with the evolution of water and ethanol as the by-product of imidization. It can be seen that the B-staged oligoimide resins thermally treated at <150°C would loss ˜30% of its original weight when the temperature was scanned from 100°C to 250°C. This is mainly derived from the solvent and the by-product (water and ethanol) of the amidization and imidization of the poly(amic ester) resin.

caption.p: FTIR spectra of a PMR poly(amic ester) resin (PI-1) with different thermal baking temperatures. FTIR: Fourier transform infrared; PMR: polymerizable monomer reactant; PI: polyimide.
TGA curves of a PMR poly(amic ester) resin (PI-1) with different thermal baking temperatures. TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; PMR: polymerizable monomer reactant; PI: polyimide.

sec.p: The chemical structures of the B-staged oligoimide resins were investigated. Figure 5 is the FTIR spectra of a B-staged oligoimide resin. The B-staged oligoimide resin exhibited absorptions around 1775 and 1720 cm−1 (imide C=O asymmetric and symmetric stretching), 1590 cm−1 (aromatic C=C stretching), and 1370 cm−1 (imide C–N stretching). Meanwhile, a small peak at 2210 cm−1 was attributed to the stretching vibrations of the phenylethynyl groups in the B-staged oligoimide resin.

caption.p: Fourier transform infrared spectra of B-staged oligoimide resins.

sec.p: The molecular weights of two B-staged oligoimide resins, PI-3 and PI-8, determined by GPC are summarized in Table 2. The M ns of the oligomers determined by GPC were a little greater than the calculated ones with polydispersities of 1.6–1.7. The small peaks observed for PI-8 in GPC curve as shown in Figure 6 might be attributed to the lower molecular weight components due to the higher stoichiometric offset of the 2500 g mol−1 oligoimide. Generally, the GPC results were in accordance with the trend of the designed molecular weights, indicating that the B-staged pre-PI resins had the expected chemical structures as drawn in Figure 1.

caption.p: Gel permeation chromatography curves of B-staged oligoimide resins.
Molecular weight of the B-staged oligoimide resins.

fn.p: PI: polyimide; Calcd M n: calculated molecular weight.

sec.p: The XRD patterns of the B-staged oligoimide resins (PI-1 to PI-5) are shown in Figure 7. PI-1 derived from s-BPDA showed a sharp diffraction peak at 15°, while the other PIs did not exhibit any diffraction peaks, indicating that the insertion of α-BPDA into the polymer backbones has changed the polymer chain aggregation. In other words, the asymmetric structure of α-BPDA reduced the regularity of polymer chains and the crystallizability of the oligoimide resins, resulting in the oligoimide resins with amorphous states. 21–23

caption.p: X-Ray diffraction curves of B-staged oligoimide resins.

sec.title: Meltability of the B-staged oligoimide resins
sec.p: Figure 8 depicts the rheological behaviors of the B-staged oligoimide resins, which were performed by ramping the temperature from 250°C to 400°C at a heating rate of 4°C min−1 for the powder molded discs. The B-staged oligoimide resin with semicrystallized state (PI-1) exhibited very high melt viscosity at the temperatures as high as 330–340°C. However, the minimum melt viscosities of the B-staged oligoimide resins with amorphous state were significantly reduced by increasing the mole ratios of α-BPDA/(α-BPDA + s-BPDA) in the resin chemical compositions, especially when the mole ratio was over 20% (Table 3). For instance, PI-3 (20% of α-BPDA) shows the minimum melt viscosity of 185 Pa·s at 364°C, much lower than PI-2 (η m = 315 Pa·s at 376°C) with 10% of α-BPDA and PI-1 (η m = 6270 Pa.s at 366°C) without α-BPDA, respectively. Meanwhile, the temperatures at the minimum melt viscosity (T m) decreased with the increase in the α-BPDA loadings. For instance, PI-5 (50% of α-BPDA) showed the T m of 349°C, which was 15°C lower than PI-3 (364°C, 20% of α-BPDA) and 27°C lower than PI-2 (376°C, 10% of α-BPDA), respectively, demonstrating that the incorporating of α-BPDA in the B-staged oligoimide resins reduced not only the resin’s melt viscosity but also the melting temperatures, thus improving the melt processability of the resins.

caption.p: Melt viscosities of the B-staged oligoimides with Calcd M n = 5000 g mol.−1

tr.th: Temperature scale with η m < 500 Pa·s

fn.p: PI: polyimide; Calcd M n: calculated molecular weight.

caption.p: Rheology behaviors of the B-staged oligoimide resins ((a) 5000 g mol−1 version; (b) 2500 g mol−1 version).

sec.p: Another improvement by incorporating α-BPDA in the polymer backbone of B-staged oligoimide resin was the extended melting processing windows (Table 3). With the increasing α-BPDA loadings in the resin’s backbones, the B-staged oligoimide resins with Calcd M n = 5000 g mol−1 showed extended temperature scale where the resin’s melt viscosity was lower than 500 Pa·s (T w). In comparison, PI-3 (20% of α-BPDA) and PI-4 (30% of α-BPDA) showed the T w of 42–48°C when compared with the T w of 30°C (360–390°C) for PI-2 (10% of α-BPDA), implying that melt processing widows were improved by increasing the α-BPDA loadings in the B-staged resin’s composition.

Additionally, reducing the Calcd M n of the oligoimides was also an effective approach to reduce the melt viscosities. The B-staged oligoimide resins with Calcd M n of 2500 g mol−1 (Figure 8(b)) showed much lower melt viscosities than those with Calcd M n of 5000 g mol−1 (Figure 8(a)). For instance, PI-8 (Calcd M n = 2500 g mol−1) had a melt viscosity of 27 Pa·s at 340°C when compared with 185 Pa·s at 364°C for PI-3 (Calcd M n = 5000 g mol−1) with the same chemical compositions (Table 4).

caption.p:
Melt viscosities of the B-staged oligoimides with Calcd M n = 2500 g mol.−
1

tr.th: Temperature scale with η m < 100 Pa·s

fn.p: PI: polyimide; Calcd M n: calculated molecular weight.

sec.p: Hence, copolymerization of s-BPDA and a-BPDA with aromatic diamines not only efficiently reduced the melt viscosities of the B-staged oligoimide resins but also widened the melt processing windows. In addition, reducing the Calcd M n of the oligoimide was also an effective way to improve the melt processability. However, this is accomplished with a compromise in mechanical properties.

sec.title: Thermal and mechanical properties of thermally cured PI neat resins
sec.p: Figure 9 shows the DMA curves of the PI neat resins thermally cured at 370°C/2 h. The storage modulus did not drop down until the temperature was scanned up to 270°C and the glass transition temperatures, defined as the tanδ, were all above 280°C (Table 5). The thermal decomposition temperature (T d) and the temperature at 5% loss of original weight were all above 530°C, indicating that the PI resins had great thermal stability.

caption.p: DMA curves of the PI neat resins thermally cured at 370°C/2 h. DMA: dynamic mechanical analysis; PI: polyimide.
Thermal and mechanical properties of the thermally cured PI neat resins at 370°C/2 h.

fn.p: TGA: thermogravimetric analysis; DMA: dynamic mechanical analysis; PI: polyimide; T d: thermal decomposition temperature.

sec.p: Table 5 shows the mechanical properties of the thermally cured PI neat resins. The tensile modulus of the cured resins was a little lower than some reported literatures, which might be due to different forms of the testing samples. 17 For the thermally cured PI neat resins with Calcd M n of 5000 g mol−1 (PI-3 and PI-4), the tensile strengths were over 124 MPa and the elongations at break were >16%. The flexural strengths were >150 MPa and flexural moduli were >3.1 GPa, showing good combination of strength, modulus, and toughness. In comparison, the PI resins with Calcd M n of 2500 g mol−1 showed reduced mechanical strength and toughness. For instance, the tensile strength of PI-8 and PI-9 were 95.1 MPa and 59.2 MPa, respectively, much lower than PI-3 and PI-4. Meanwhile, the elongation at breakage was reduced to 6.3% for PI-8 and 3.9% for PI-9, respectively, demonstrating that lowering the Calcd M n of the PI resins could obviously reduced the mechanical strength and toughness. During the thermal curing of the B-staged phenylethynyl endcapped oligoimide resins, PI chain extension and cross-linking occurred simultaneously at the elevated curing temperatures. 24 In this process, the chain extension yielded the resins with high-molecular-weights, beneficial to improve the strength and toughness while the chain cross-linking led to the resins with high modulus and high T g.

In comparison with the series of the PI resins with different chemical structures and Calcd M n as discussed above, PI-3 had the best combination of mechanical and thermal properties, along with the good melt processability, which was selected as a candidate to prepare the Cf/PI composites.

sec.title: Cf -reinforced PI composites
sec.p: Continuous T300 Cf was impregnated with PI-3 matrix resin solution to fabricate Cf/PI prepreg. The prepreg was cut and plied up into desired size and directions, and then cured in a hot press under 1.5 MPa. The thermal processing cycles were optimized as shown in Figure 10 to give a high-quality unidirectional and quasi-isotropic composite laminates. Figure 11 shows the cross-section photomicrographs of a quasi-isotropic composite laminate. It can be seen that no voids or defects could be observed in any layer of the quasi-isotropic laminate, and the Cf volume fraction was about 57–58% as calculated from these images.

caption.p: The optimized thermal curing cycle for the B-staged carbon fiber prepreg.
Cross-section photomicrographs of a quasi-isotropic laminate ((a) ×100, overview of the cross-section; (b) ×1000, 90° ply; (c) ×1000, 0° ply; (d) ×1000, 45° ply).

sec.p: In order to determine whether the B-staged oligoimide resins were completely cured in the Cf composites, the Cf/PI composite laminates prepared by thermal curing at 370°C/2 h were further post-cured at 380°C for another 2 h and 4 h. Figure 12 compares the DMA curves of the T300/PI-3 composites with different post-curing conditions. It can be seen that the onset value of storage modulus (E′onset) and the peak value of tan δ of the composites post-cured at 380°C were extended to the higher temperatures (Table 6). The composites post-cured at 380°C for 4 h showed E′onset of 276°C and tan δ of 291°C, respectively, 14°C and 11°C higher than that without post-curing, implying that the post-curing at 380°C is beneficial to produce the composites with better thermal properties.

caption.p: DMA curves of the composite laminates with different post-curing treatments. DMA: dynamic mechanical analysis.
DMA data of the carbon fiber composites with different post-curing treatments.

sec.p: Table 7 shows the mechanical properties of the T300/PI-3 unidirectional laminates tested at different elevated temperatures. The flexural strength of the composite was 1536.8 ± 86.7 MPa at room temperature, 1137.9 ± 71.8 MPa at 177°C (74.0%), 972.1 ± 45.8 MPa at 230°C (63.3%), and 819.1 ± 36.2 MPa at 250°C (53.3%), respectively. The flexural modulus was 143.8 ± 4.6 GPa at room temperature, only 2.6% of loss at 250°C (140.0 ± 0.9 GPa) exhibiting great modulus retention at elevated temperatures. The interlaminar shear strength was 108.1 ± 2.7 MPa, lowering to 62.8 ± 3.9 MPa at 230°C (58.1%), and 52.8 ± 2.6 MPa at 250°C (48.8%), respectively. These results indicated that the T300/PI-3 composite might be long-term served at a temperature as high as 250°C.

caption.p: Mechanical properties of the T300/PI-3 composite laminates.

fn.p: CAI: compression strength after impact; PI: polyimide.

sec.p: In addition, the CAI strength measured on quasi-isotropic laminates after impacted at an energy of 6.7 kJ m−1 was 259.8 ± 13.2 MPa, and the OHC and OHT were 303.2 ± 17.5 MPa and 366.9 ± 49.9 MPa, respectively, indicating that the composite has high impact toughness. When comparing with the study of Smith et al. 17 , the OHC and CAI strength showed a little decrease in this work, indicating that incorporating asymmetric structure have certain negative effect on the toughness of PI composites. But there are some other factors affecting these results such as the types of Cf, the layup, the processing condition of PI composites, the differences of testing details between different works, and so on. Therefore, the effect of asymmetric structure on toughness might need a more systematic and comprehensive work that will be part of our following research.

The optical images (Figure 13) and C-scan images (Figure 14) of specimens before and after impacted were compared. After impacted, no obvious damage could be observed on the composite panel surface and only a small circular delamination area in the center of the testing panel was determined by the C-scan testing, indicating that the composite showed good damage tolerance.

caption.p: Optical images of the Cf/PI composite laminates ((a) fresh testing panel; (b) after impact; (c) after compression). Cf: carbon fiber; PI: polyimide.
C-scan images of the Cf/PI composite laminates ((a) before impact; (b) after impact). Cf: carbon fiber; PI: polyimide.

sec.p: In order to further understand the relationship between the impact energy and the compressive strength after impact (CAI), four energy levels of 2.3 kJ m−1, 4.5 kJ m−1, 6.7 kJ m−1, and 8.9 kJ m−1 were employed in the impact testing experiments. As expected, higher impact energies resulted in larger damage areas and lower CAI values (Table 8). There was a positive correlation between the impact energies and the damage areas, while there was a negative correlation between the impact energies and the CAI values (Figure 15). When the impact energy was increased to 8.9 kJ m−1, the CAI value of the testing laminate was also as high as 230 MPa, indicating very high impact toughness.

caption.p: Experiment results after impact at different energy levels.
Relationship between the impact energies and compression strength after impact values.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Toughened PMR PI matrix resins were prepared, which could be thermally heated to form the B-staged oligoimide resins. After thermally cured at 370°C/2 h, the B-staged oligoimide resins were converted to PIs with good combination of mechanical, thermal, and melt-processing properties. The Cf composite laminate (T300/PI-3) prepared using the PMR matrix resins showed an impact toughness (CAI) as high as 260 MPa (impact energy = 6.7 kJ m−1). The unidirectional composite laminate also had excellent mechanical properties at room temperature. Importantly, the T300/PI-3 unidirectional composite laminate showed high strength retention at 250°C, with 97.4% for flexural modulus (140 GPa), 53.3% for flexural strength (819.1 MPa), and 48.8% for ILSS (52.8 MPa), respectively, indicating that the high impact-toughened T300/PI-3 composite could be long-term served at the temperature as high as 250°C.

fn.label: Funding
fn.p: This study was supported by a funding from National Natural Science Foundation of China (NSFC; No. 50903087).
